message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination suggest leiomyomas, which have whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders on biopsy. Option A describes leiomyosarcoma, option B describes psammomatous calcification seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma and meningioma, and option C describes adenomyosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings suggest leiomyoma, a benign tumor of the uterus that is characterized by a whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders, which is the histological characteristic described in option D. Option A describes leiomyosarcoma, a malignant tumor of the uterus. Option B describes psammoma bodies, which are commonly seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma and meningiomas. Option C describes adenomyosis, a condition in which endometrial tissue is found within the myometrium of the uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with uterine leiomyomas, also known as fibroids. The whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders is a histological characteristic of uterine leiomyomas. Clustered pleomorphic, hyperchromatic smooth muscle cells with extensive mitosis are characteristic of leiomyosarcoma. Laminated, concentric spherules with dystrophic calcification are characteristic of psammoma bodies, which are associated with certain types of tumors. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma in the myometrium is characteristic of adenomyosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings are suggestive of leiomyomas (fibroids), which are benign tumors of the uterus. The histological characteristic of leiomyomas is a whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders. Option A describes leiomyosarcoma, an extremely rare malignant tumor. Option B is characteristic of psammomatous calcifications seen in some types of ovarian tumors. Option C describes adenomyosis, a condition where endometrial tissue is found within the myometrium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The enlarged, asymmetrical, firm uterus with multiple palpable masses suggests the patient has leiomyomas, also known as fibroids, which are benign tumors of the smooth muscle of the uterus. The whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders is the classic description of leiomyomas. Option A describes leiomyosarcoma, a rare malignant tumor of the uterine smooth muscle, and is not consistent with the patient's benign condition. Option B describes uterine papillary serous carcinoma, which is associated with endometrial cancer, and the patient's biopsy confirmed a benign condition. Option C describes adenomyosis, which is the presence of endometrial glands and stroma in the myometrium, and is also not consistent with the patient's diagnosis of leiomyomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest leiomyoma (uterine fibroids). The histological characteristic seen in leiomyoma is a whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders. Option A describes leiomyosarcoma, option B describes psammomatous calcifications seen in ovarian serous cystadenoma, and option C describes adenomyosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of uterine fibroids, which are benign tumors of the uterine smooth muscle. The histological characteristic typically seen on biopsy is a whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders. Option A describes leiomyosarcoma, which is a malignant tumor of smooth muscle. Option B describes psammomatous calcifications seen in ovarian serous tumors. Option C describes adenomyosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination findings suggest leiomyomas or fibroids, and the histological characteristic of whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders is typical of leiomyomas. Choice A describes leiomyosarcoma, a malignant condition. Choice B describes psammoma bodies seen in ovarian cancer or papillary thyroid cancer. Choice C describes adenomyosis, which is endometrial tissue within the myometrium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest leiomyoma. Among the options, only (D) describes the characteristic appearance of leiomyoma, which includes a whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders. (A) describes leiomyosarcoma, a malignant neoplasm, which is not indicated in the question. (B) describes psammoma bodies, which are commonly seen in serous tumors. (C) describes adenomyosis, which is characterized by endometrial glands and stroma in the myometrium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest uterine fibroids, which are benign tumors of the uterine smooth muscle. The whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-defined borders is the most characteristic feature of uterine fibroids on biopsy. Options A and B are characteristics of leiomyosarcoma and calcified uterine fibroids, respectively, which are both more rare and more dangerous conditions than uterine fibroids. Option C describes adenomyosis, which is a separate condition from uterine fibroids.
